title: Bandwidth Calculator (Download Time)

seo.title: Data Transfer Calculator | Estimate Download & Upload Time
seo.description: How long will it take to transfer your file? Calculate download/upload duration based on file size and internet speed. Supports TB, GB, MB and Gbps, Mbps.

summary: Waiting for a download? Find out exactly when it will finish. Useful for large game updates, server migrations, and video uploads.

faq.q: Why is my download slower than the calculator says?
faq.a: Real-world speeds are affected by server load (the sender), network congestion (the road), and your hardware (the receiver). This calculator assumes a consistent speed, but internet connections fluctuate.

faq.q: What is the difference between Mbps and MB/s?
faq.a: This is the most common confusion. ISPs advertise speeds in **Megabits** (Mbps). File sizes are in **Megabytes** (MB). 1 Byte = 8 bits. So, a 100 Mbps connection is actually 12.5 MB/s.
When you send a file, you aren't just sending the file data. You are also sending 'packaging' (headers, checksums, handshakes). TCP/IP overhead typically adds 2-10% to the total data transmitted.

faq.q: How many GB is a 4K movie?
faq.a: A typical 2-hour 4K movie stream is about 14 GB. A high-quality 4K Blu-ray rip can be 50-80 GB.

article.heading: The Bit vs. Byte Confusion
article.body:
The primary reason people miscalculate download times is the unit mismatch.

*   **b (lowercase) = bit:** The smallest unit of data (0 or 1). Network speeds are measured in bits (e.g., 1 Gbps).
*   **B (uppercase) = Byte:** 8 bits. Storage is measured in Bytes (e.g., 1 TB SSD).

**The Formula:**
`Time = (File Size x 8) / Internet Speed`

Example: To download a 10 GB game on a 100 Mbps connection:
1.  10 GB = 10,000 MB = 80,000 Megabits.
2.  80,000 Megabits / 100 Mbps = 800 seconds.
3.  800 seconds â‰ˆ 13 minutes.

article.heading: Network Bottlenecks
article.body:
Your transfer is only as fast as the slowest link in the chain.
1.  **The Server:** Steam or Google Drive might limit how fast they send data to you.
2.  **The Router:** An old Wi-Fi router might cap out at 300 Mbps even if you pay for 1 Gbps fiber.
3.  **The Drive:** A mechanical Hard Drive (HDD) writes data at ~100 MB/s. If you have Gigabit internet (125 MB/s), your disk drive is the bottleneck, not your internet.

article.heading: Overhead: The Hidden Tax
article.body: Every packet of data sent over the internet is wrapped in metadata (TCP/IP headers) ensuring it arrives at the correct destination. This 'packaging' takes up space. A 10% overhead is a safe real-world estimate. If you need to move 100 GB, you are actually transmitting closer to 110 GB of data.
